The New Story on Whiskey Row | Whisky Magazine Become a Member BECOME A MEMBER FREE LITE MEMBERSHIP Search whiskymag.com for: Articles Tastings Become A Member Articles Tastings Magazine Awards & Events Icons of Whisky Whisky Live World Whiskies Awards Shop Whisky Magazine Arbikie 2017 Highland Rye 7 Years Old Whisky Magazine Editor's Blend 2021 Whisky Magazine Editor's Blend 2022 Whisky Magazine Editor's Blend 2024 Whisky Magazine Glengoyne 16 Years Old Search whiskymag.com for: Articles Tastings Home > Articles > The New Story on Whiskey Row The New Story on Whiskey Row Dave Waddell finds a visitor centre with a twist Places | 21 Mar 2014 | Issue 118 | By Dave Waddell Share to: Here's a well worn fact: today's big brands are sold on the idea of the experiential story - whisky or otherwise. Well worn because, as Walt Disney showed the world, as far back as 1964, at the New York Trade Fair, live promenade-type story making, the type in which you, honoured guest, are invited to dive in, is an old and much explored art form. Fact because you can't move now for mention of the word: story, as concept, is the new sell, the Holy Grail, the pot at the end of the rainbow. Every marketing department knows this. Unfortunately, as Adam Scott - designer, architect and champion of the so-called built story, and with whom (full disclosure), in another life, and on various projects, I've had the opportunity to work - rightly says, most big brand marketing departments make plane crashes out of their storytelling. Whatever the intention, says Scott, however well-meaning the brief, the story, when actually told, collapses in on itself, its qualities, its feints, its draws, its surprises and rewards, now reduced to, either, on the one hand, a clutch of brand truths chased down by a welcoming glass of champagne; or, on the other, to an event in which money precedes all thought, one so extravagant as to loosen itself entirely of its original purpose. The first is a pleasant lecture, the second a dictator's pool party. I'm not being fair. I've had some wonderful experiences, not least, and for example, a multi-distillery funded surprise dinner beside a loch on Islay, an intimate and very homespun piece of storytelling that, as Scott might say, made liberal use of Walt Disney's recipe for creating a compelling, believable tale, one in which I was both delighted and unwitting protagonist. However, such an experience, one that began in a deserted and overgrown car park, saw a piper emerge from the green, to lead us through the forest and into an evening as simple as it was beautiful, is memorable as much for the quality of its very rareness as it is that of the story it tells. Compare it to the average car launch if you will. What joy, then, to have chanced, at the end of last year, on Heaven Hill's brand new Evan Williams Bourbon Experience, on Main Road, Louisville, Kentucky. Heaven Hill, you will know, is the Shapira family owned distillery that has had, since its inception in 1935, a Beam as its master distiller, that continues, as far as I am aware, to produce and lay down whisky not only for itself, but also for an unspecified number of nondistiller whisky producers, and that, in 1996, lost its original Bardstown distillery and seven warehouses to a fire. Evan Williams is one of its two flagship Bourbons - the other being Elijah Craig. Its new distillery sits on the old Bernheim site. Its standard recipe is a mashbill of 78 per cent corn, 10 per cent rye and 12 per cent malted barley, though its contract work and the fact it acquired Old Fitzgerald, a wheated Bourbon, from Diageo in 1992, further developed as the super premium Larceny, means that Heaven Hill is home to two or more Bourbon formulas, to which add three further recipes, for its corn and rye whiskies and for a straight wheated whisky. It has a total of 84 whisky line extensions. Heaven Hill's a serial creator-maker, no mistake. So, to the point. Heaven Hill has come up with a visitors' centre (if you're going anytime soon, look away: I'm about to let the main cat out of the bag) that is also a bona fide working micro-distillery, and has done so in such a way as to qualify for a form of experiential storytelling that takes as its core the best of Walt Disney circa 1964, and then some. Let me explain. First, it's perfectly placed, perfectly timed and makes perfect sense: Old Whiskey Row, in a building once occupied by the Phillip Hollenbach company, pre-prohibition whisky distributors for the likes of Old Fortuna, Old Tom, Old Coxey and Pride of the West, just yards away from where Evan Williams set up his first commercial distillery, close to Heaven Hill's present distillery and at a time when Louisville is expertly surfing the Bourbon wave. It's the inevitable result, says Larry Lass, Director of Corporate Communications, of a 'perfect storm.' Second, it tells a story - of a day in the life of Evan Williams, of Heaven Hill's present production methods, of whisky being made, of a history that promenades down Whiskey Row, and finishes in one of two period tasting rooms - that begins in such a way, as Scott would say, as to both reinforce and, at the same time, disrupt our expectations. Main Street, Louisville, you may know, is a street made of giants. A life-size and golden replica of Michaelangelo's David stands just a block away. A 120 foot to scale copy of Babe Ruth's 34 inch bat leans up against the Louisville Slugger Museum. The Mohammed Ali Centre is across the road. The street traces Kentucky's lifeblood, the Ohio River. Big things shouting big stuff. Small wonder, then, that the Evan Williams Bourbon Experience should feature a fa√ßade that is a five-storey high upended bottle of Evan Williams, which at around the second storey morphs down into a 3D neck-and-lowball-glass working fountain. Only, the surprise here is not the giant, but rather its position, and therefore its relative quietness. It's on the inside, looking out. You can't see it - until you're standing directly in front of it. The pavement is just this, the pavement. Heaven Hill's giant doesn't compete with - or repeat - the street. It doesn't need to. It's a quiet giant, an invisible roar, an oxymoron. It silently hooks. See it, finally, and you're going in. Third, it's how Heaven Hill - or, more specifically, Solid Light, the design agency commissioned for the project - plays with both the characterisation and the structure of this story that makes the experience of visiting the centre so radically different. It's utterly, to borrow a much hackneyed phrase, immersive. It's film and its period-staged experiences (projected surround nightlit windows, a riverside shot growing out of real riverside grass, two roomsized screens depicting front and back views, the 2D action taking place about a late eighteenth century still) are designed to create spaces in history, delightful, illusory vignettes that progress us through the life, thinking and character of a close-enough-totouch Williams, the result the distinct impression that you are, like some benign voyeur, experiencing a genuine Back to the Futuremoment, a fission of hyper-reality. You are standing right inside the story. This is clever, and great fun, and revisited later, upstairs, in slightly more traditional form, in either of the tasting rooms. One is a remodel of an early 20th century Hollenbach reception room, the other a lounge lizard type 1960s homage to Max and Harry Shapiro; but really, however fine the melding of the now with the then, whatever the technical wizadry of an integrated system run off your guide's cell phone, the brilliant theatre of corridors that walk you through a century of Bourbon history, the success of the story rests, prepares for, circles, reflects on the unveiling of a moment that is as unexpected as it is wonderful. Fifteen minutes in, trapped in a darkish corridor, a dioramic video wall display of the distillery's production methods at an end, the voice of an Evan Williams sound-alike, our sonic uber-narrator, fading to nothing, your guide will ask you to step forward, turn around and with the press of a button raise the (electric) curtains on the main event: a working micro-distillery. Here beats the story's heart. No longer propelled by the carefully choreographed narrative of either an historical character or the way Heaven Hill makes its whiskey, I am suddenly deposited into the live world of the production floor, to make what I like of what I see. Here it is: A gleaming pair of purpose-made Vendome micro-pot stills, at least two raised stainless steel fermenting vats, wash and spirits tray boxes, two holding tanks, one for the low wines, the other compartmentalised, the new make's coming off the still right now, head and tail separated off from the main cut. I learn that the man passing below, making the cut, is Charlie Downs, that the cooking (four hours) and half of the fermenting (four days) takes place out of sight, in the basement, and that the low wine comes off at between 70 and 80 proof, today's heart is at 142 proof, whereupon it'll be barrelled and whisked off, for now, to the top two floors of Warehouse Y, Nelson County, one of Heaven Hill's 51 warehouses. And because today is this day, I get to meet Downs, ex-supervisor of the main distillery, and now delighted master of an operation as different, he says, as 'going from a Volkswagen to a Cadillac.' He says it's like 'going back in time'. He says he's 'babying it more'. He says he's 'still learning.' This from a man who's been helping Heaven Hill make whisky from as far back as when Lyndon B Johnson was beginning to ramp up America's involvement in Vietnam. And what, say he, the quality of the white dog? 'I believe this is going to be even a little bit better than Bernheim.' To which Kass will later add that the mashbill's slightly different, for reasons, he says, of both taste and having to accommodate the pot-based nature of the stills (I won't get more from him on this); that Downs controls the reflux manually, and limits himself to working off the bottom two trays, the higher ones posing too much of a threat 'to flavour'; and that there are plans to make not just bourbon here, but also rye and wheat whiskies, and to experiment with different mashbills. I am a character in a story, a bit of which is being told for the very first time. And there's the rub. I will, in a minute, go up the stairs that are also a microexample of the Heaven Hill's rickhouse setup, settle into tasting a shot of Evan Williams Single Barrel against the Larceny, and exit, eventually, through the gift shop. Like the start, it will be a fine experience, though this time, as Scott might say, one designed to reward rather than hook and hold. It's a taste of the story, and then the chance to take some of it away. It's neat, a pick-me-up ending, and no loose ends. However, none of this, the final exchange, or what, indeed, went before, the giant fa√ßade, the high-tech odes to both Evan Williams and Heaven Hill (yes, true: however factually put, this is still a herobrand writing songs to itself and for us), none of it hangs together without the smell of corn cooking, the roar of machine, the material nowness of the centre's distillery. The distillery provides the tale its moment of poetry. An unexpected and visceral turn, a movement that carries everything with it, inviting in the process multiple interpretations, and projecting bits of itself (barrels of whisky) into the future, it's the real, the living pulsing centre of a story called the Evan William's Bourbon Experience. It's inclusive. It's generous. It's bold storytelling. Which is why you must go, now, or tomorrow, at the very latest. Walt Disney would. Whiskytree Inc, Visual Effects and Content Creation Skip to content Committed Artists & Technicians Master Crafted Creativity Highest Standard of Quality Master Crafted Creativity Highest Standard of Quality Committed Artists & Technicians Search for: Welcome What We Do Who We Are Contact Join Us Craftsmanship Welcome What We Do Who We Are Contact Join Us Craftsmanship Home ‚Äì 2025/04/17 Alanna Pickerrell 2025-06-25T14:36:16-07:00 Whiskytree is a visual effects and content creation company that is equal parts agency & production company, as well as a computer graphics powerhouse. Our work spans industries and generations. You are just as likely to find it on the silver screen as you are on television, the internet, in an app, a game, VR or AR, or on the cover of a book. If you have a creative challenge and want to engage with a world-class team of artists, designers, and technicians, look no further. Welcome to Whiskytree! Whiskytree is a visual effects and content creation company that is equal parts agency & production company, as well as a computer graphics powerhouse. Our work spans industries and generations. You are just as likely to find it on the silver screen as you are on television, the internet, in an app, a game, VR or AR, or on the cover of a book. If you have a creative challenge and want to engage with a world-class team of artists, designers, and technicians, look no further. Welcome to Whiskytree! Aidan Fraser √ó Aidan Fraser Visual Effects Supervisor With over 20 years of experience in Visual Effects, Aidan Fraser has worked on such projects as Star Wars: Episode III, King Kong, four of the five Pirates of the Caribbean films, two Star Trek movies, Wonder Woman 1984, and recently Obi-Wan Kenobi. He also has experience working on episodic shows and animated features. As a Visual Effects Supervisor at Whiskytree, Aidan works with and guides our talented artists to make stunning visuals for some of the world‚Äôs biggest feature and episodic projects. Aidan holds a degree in Film and Digital media from UCSC, and has been involved in some kind of filmmaking project or another since the age of 7. His career informally started at the age of 15, when he won The Visions of US Award from the American Film Institute. When not at work, Aidan enjoys the outdoors as well as landscape photography. ‚ÄúThere is a great sense of collaboration at Whiskytree. I think we are all driven to create something never seen before.‚Äù Haunted Mansion, The Mandalorian: Season 3, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, Andor, Obi-Wan Kenobi, Kingdom, Space Sweepers, Wonder Woman 1984, Ad Astra, Love, Death & Robots, Velvet Buzzsaw, 7 Splinters in Time, The Cloverfield Paradox, Rings, Office Christmas Party, Star Trek Beyond, Scouts Guide to the Zombie Apocalypse, The Walk, Cosmos: A Spacetime Odyssey, Need for Speed, Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones, The Lone Ranger, Star Trek: Secrets of the Universe, Star Trek: Into Darkness, Space Out, ParaNorman, Lifeline, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1, The Other Guys, Iron Man 2, Percy Jackson & the Olympians: The Lightning Thief, Surrogates, The Warrior and the Wolf, Coraline, Adam, The Narrows, The Heart is a Hidden Camera, Pirates of the Caribbean: At World‚Äôs End, Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man‚Äôs Chest, King Kong, Star Wars: Episode III ‚Äì Revenge of the Sith, xXx: State of the Union, My Big Fat Independent Movie, The V-Party, The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl 3-D, Van Helsing, Peter Pan, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl, Independent Lens, Off the Charts: The Song-Poem Story, The Broken Wings of Elijah Footfalls, Space Out, The Last Supper, Limbo Paul Hudson √ó Paul Hudson Tools Developer Paul holds a degree in computer science and engineering with a minor in film from the University of Akron. In high school, Paul painted his bedroom wall as a blue screen and for his 10th grade research paper he chose to write about Jurassic Park, noting that it was a crossover of the different philosophies of Phil Tippett and Dennis Muren. At Whiskytree, Paul leads most programming and app building tasks including the development of custom tools needed for various projects. His ability to bridge the gap between technical and artistic frameworks allows him to assist his fellow artists in problem solving so that they can complete tasks easier, better, and faster. Hailing from a small town in Ohio, Paul enjoys city life in San Francisco where he and his wife, Melissa are raising their children. In his free time, Paul enjoys traveling, attending concerts at intimate venues and neighborhood exploration. With an eye for framing and composition, Paul is an avid photographer. Paul is the godfather of Salsa Friday, a weekly Whiskytree ritual that caps the week with salsa music, chips and dip. ‚ÄúThis is a labor of love. Many in our group could be working in a booming Silicon Valley startup but they choose to work here, in VFX.‚Äù Day of Reckoning, The Gorge, Before, Masters of the Air, The Marvels, Haunted Mansion, The Out-Laws, The Mandalorian: Season 3, Babylon, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, Andor, Obi-Wan Kenobi, The Bubble, Foundation, Nightbooks, Godmothered, The Captain, Bolden, The Other Side of the Wind, Shatterbox, Skyscraper, Perfect, Monster Hunt 2,The Hunger Games: Mockingjay ‚Äì Part 1, Elysium, Thor, Hereafter, Alice in Wonderland, The Mist, Evan Almighty, Spider-Man 3, Snakes on a Plane, Sin City Michael Kennen √ó Michael Kennen Compositing Supervisor Michael has been a part of the commercial and motion picture industry since the early 90‚Äôs. After working as an assistant feature film editor in Los Angeles, Michael moved back to the San Francisco Bay Area and worked for many years at the commercial post production house Varitel Video. He worked his way up from assistant editor to colorist and finally to Flame compositor. In the early 2000‚Äôs, Michael moved from the commercial industry to the motion picture industry while he worked as a compositor utilizing various programs such as Flame, Shake, After Effects, and Nuke. During this time, Michael worked for numerous VFX companies such as ILM, Sony Imageworks, Rhythm + Hues, Tippett Studio and The Orphanage, to name a few. Michael joined Whiskytree in 2014 as Senior Compositor, and has since worked on a wide variety of projects, including films, commercials, games, and virtual reality worlds. ‚ÄúI was drawn to Whiskytree by the size of the company,the quality of work, and the skill level of the artists working here.‚Äù The Gorge, Before, Masters of the Air, The Marvels, Haunted Mansion, Babylon, Andor, Obi-Wan, Kenobi, The Bubble, Foundation, Nightbooks, Godmothered, The Captain, Bolden, The Other Side of the Wind, Shatterbox, Skyscraper, Perfect, Monster Hunt 2, Thor: Ragnarok, Rogue One: A Star Wars Story, Transformers: The Last Knight, Tomorrowland, The Revenant, The Last Witch Hunter, The Big Short, Thor: The Dark World, Star Trek, Pacific Rim, Chasing Mavericks, The Amazing Spiderman, Battleship, Cirque Du Soleil, Ghost Rider: Spirit of Vengeance, Super 8, Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides, Transformers: Dark of the Moon, Mars Needs Moms, The Other Guys, Iron Man 2, Alice in Wonderland, The Box, The Spiderwick Chronicles, Live Free or Die Hard, Pirates of the Caribbean: At World‚Äôs End, Zodiac, The Messengers, The Last Mimzy, The Good Shepherd, Superman II: The Richard Donner Cut, Danika, Pan‚Äôs Labyrinth, King Kong, The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl, Sin City, Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed, The Cat in the Hat, Seabiscuit, Baby Bob Andrew Martin √ó Andrew Martin Studio Manager (Georgia) & Associate Producer Andrew has a background in Animation and Computer Science, combining the two majors for a broader understanding of the VFX process. This dual perspective allows him to tackle production tasks using methods not normally considered. Andrew has worked in motion graphics for children‚Äôs media in Chicago, in Render Wrangling for animated features, and in VFX production management for film, theme attractions, and commercials. He has had opportunities to work on-set supporting VFX Supervisors and matchmove artists as well as wrangling set data. At Whiskytree, Andrew is the Studio Manager for the Georgia location and Associate Producer focusing on day-to-day communications, scheduling, and organization. His technical skills are also leveraged for workflow optimization. Ensuring artists are able to focus on their areas of expertise by documenting and working through organizational and technical challenges is one of his motivating factors. A Midwestern native from Ohio, Andrew enjoys staying active with hiking and swimming during the week and barefoot waterskiing on the weekends. He also enjoys volunteering with various community groups, watching or reading science fiction, and exploring new areas. ‚ÄúCollaborative storytelling with a cohesive team is a rewarding and inspiring environment for those of us in production management‚Äù. In college, she studied acting, stage lighting, and majored in TV/Radio with a focus to work in the film industry. In her spare time, she taught herself how to build computers and write software. After college, Emerald moved to New York City and tried bartending. Still flying half a ship, she happily landed a gig a few years later in San Francisco as a software developer. Together they enjoy exploring the Bay Area, trying new cuisines, and finding other dog-friendly activities. ‚ÄúWe have a consistent visual identity and good company culture.‚Äù The Gorge, Masters of the Air, The Mandalorian: Season 3, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, Andor, Obi-Wan Kenobi, Foundation, Nightbooks, Godmothered, The Captain, Bolden, The Other Side of the Wind, Shatterbox, Skyscraper, Monster Hunt 2, Thor: Ragnarok, Rogue One: A Star Wars Story,Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows, Legendary, Tomorrowland, The Big Short, The Invisible Highway, The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1, Interlude, Nuisible Jonathan Harb √ó Jonathan Harb CEO & Executive Producer Jonathan owns and operates Whiskytree. During his career, he has contributed to over 80 feature films and dozens of commercials, special venue projects, and ad campaigns. Harb manages client relationships, supervises and produces the company‚Äôs work, and directs various productions that Whiskytree takes on. His film credits include visual effects executive producer, visual effects supervisor, digital matte supervisor, digital matte artist, digital artist, and concept and animatic artist. Jonathan worked at ILM from 1996-2007, and graduated summa cum laude with a degree in industrial design from The College of Design at North Carolina State University. He is a voting member of the Visual Effects Branch of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. ‚ÄúWelcome to Whiskytree.‚Äù The Gorge, Before, Masters of the Air, The Marvels, Haunted Mansion, The Out-Laws, The Mandalorian: Season 3, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, Andor, Obi-Wan Kenobi, Babylon, The Bubble, Foundation, Nightbooks, Godmothered, Skyscraper, The Other Side of the Wind, Monster Hunt 2, Thor: Ragnarok, Rogue One: A Star Wars Story, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows, The Revenant, The Big Short, The Last Witch Hunter, Tomorrowland, The Hunger Games: Mockingjay ‚Äì Part 1, Captain America: The Winter Soldier, Thor: The Dark World, Elysium, Thor, Rango, TRON: Legacy, Terminator Salvation, Bedtime Stories, Iron Man, Mission: Impossible III, Star Wars: Episode III, Peter Pan, Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl, Star Wars: Episode II, Artificial Intelligence, The Perfect Storm, Sleepy Hollow, Star Wars: Episode I, Mercury Rising, Men in Black, War of the Worlds, The Day After Tomorrow, Van Helsing, Flubber, Starship Troopers, 101 Dalmatians, The Eraser, Mars Attacks, Twister Behnam Shafiebeik √ó Behnam Shafiebeik Compositor Behnam has been working in the feature film industry for over 16 years as a Senior Compositor. His professional journey started when he was selected for the first ever Compositing Apprentice Program at Rhythm & Hues Studios in Los Angeles, CA. Upon completing the four week program, he started working on several feature films and went on to become a Lead Compositor at Rhythm & Hues. Behnam then traveled to Australia to work at Rising Sun Pictures where he was a compositor on the final chapter of the Harry Potter franchise. After that, he continued to work with many other studios, such as Weta Digital, Method Studios, and Industrial Light & Magic (ILM) ‚Äì just to name a few. After close to a decade of living and working in LA, Behnam decided to move back to his hometown of San Francisco, CA to work with ILM, where he had the opportunity to work on high profile projects such as the Transformers franchise, the Star Wars saga, Kong: Skull Island , and several of the Marvel Cinematic Universe films. Behnam‚Äôs first introduction to the team at Whiskytree came in 2019 when he was hired to help out on a project. The talented artists and leadership team made a big impression on Behnam, so when the opportunity presented itself to re-join Whiskytree in 2022, Behnam knew he couldn‚Äôt pass it up. He is so excited to be a part of such a great company. ‚ÄúThe collaborative atmosphere, respect, and license to be creative to achieve high-end visual effects while promoting a work-life balance sets Whiskytree apart from other studios‚Äù. The Gorge, Before, Masters of the Air, The Marvels, Haunted Mansion, Creation of Gods I: Kingdom of Storms, Obi-Wan Kenobi, The Book of Boba Fett, Fengshen Trilogy, The North Water, Loki, Black Widow, Star Wars: Episode IX ‚Äì The Rise of Skywalker, Playing with Water, The Captain, Aladdin, Skyscraper, Solo: A Star Wars Story, Avengers: Infinity War, A Wrinkle in Time, Star Wars: Episode VIII ‚Äì The Last Jedi, Thor: Ragnarok, Kong: Skull Island, Doctor Strange, Warcraft, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows, Captain America: Civil War, 13 Hours, Hardcore Henry, Ant-Man, Tomorrowland, Seventh Son, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles, Into the Storm, Transformers: Age of Extinction, Divergent, 300: Rise of an Empire, Thor: The Dark World, Percy Jackson: Sea of Monsters, Snow White and the Huntsman, The Cabin in the Woods, Cowboys & Aliens, Rise of the Planet of the Apes, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1, Knight and Day, Cirque de Freak: The Vampire‚Äôs Assistant, Aliens in the Attic, Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian, The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor, The Incredible Hulk, The Golden Compass, Evan Almighty, Night at the Museum, Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties Jonathan Flores √ó Jonathan Flores Generalist Jonathan Flores solves problems through art and technology. Growing up without many resources forced him to be resourceful. What started as childhood doodles became a career creating digital worlds. After teaching himself the fundamentals, he formalized his training at the Academy of Art University, where he focused on VFX principles before entering the industry. CG was the perfect fit. It required both creativity and technical problem-solving. He learned through trial, error, and endless YouTube tutorials, developing that ‚Äúfigure it out‚Äù mentality where every obstacle is just another challenge to work through. CG clicked because it demanded both sides of his brain: draw what you see and break how it works. No fancy setup, just borrowed Wi-Fi, repurposed software, and the kind of obsession that keeps you up till 3AM perfecting a single teacup render. At Whiskytree, whether designing efficient workflows or problem-solving alongside artists, he thrives on those collective ‚Äúaha‚Äù moments when a team transforms ideas into awe-inspiring VFX. Whiskytree isn‚Äôt just his first industry job, it‚Äôs where he discovered what truly matters: small teams, big heart, and limitless hustle. Here, he learned to innovate with scarcity, trust collaboration over ego, and leave a digital footprint that lasts. For Jonathan, this is more than work. It‚Äôs the realization of a dream, a Mexican-American kid with a pencil and a PC, now helping craft the visuals that define entertainment. He‚Äôs proud to pave the way for others like him: hungry artists from unconventional paths who just need a shot. When the renders finish, you‚Äôll find him deep in personal projects. 3D printing absurd solutions to nonexistent problems, modding games until they glitch beautifully, or dismantling gadgets just to rebuild them differently. The throughline? An insatiable need to understand how things work and how they could work better. For him, art and tech are never separate ‚Äì just different approaches to answering the same relentless question: ‚ÄúWhat if we tried this?‚Äù ‚Äú[I‚Äôm] proud to pave the way for others like [me]: hungry artists from unconventional paths who just need a shot.‚Äù The Gorge, Masters of the Air, Andor, Black Panther: Wakanda Forever, Obi-Wan Kenobi, The Bubble, Foundation, Nightbooks, The Captain Miranda Leighr √ó Miranda Leighr Compositor After earning her degree in Visual Effects from the Savannah College of Art and Design in 2022, Miranda moved to Atlanta to launch her career as a compositor. In just her first three years in the industry, she has contributed to more than 20 film and television projects. While compositing is her core specialty, Miranda has also been training in on-set VFX work to deepen her understanding of the filmmaking pipeline and elevate the realism in her work. Her love for visual storytelling began early‚Äîmaking green screen videos with friends using green tablecloths her parents purchased for her. It wasn‚Äôt until high school, after watching a behind-the-scenes VFX breakdown of one of her favorite films, that she decided to pursue visual effects professionally. Miranda joined Whiskytree in 2024, soon after the Alpharetta studio opened, and was immediately drawn to the collaborative energy of the team. ‚ÄúI am excited to keep learning and growing alongside such a passionate group of artists and to see where this journey takes me next.‚Äù Day of Reckoning, Before, Uglies, The Piano Lesson, Jackpot!, A Family Affair, Bad Boys: Ride or Die, BMF, The Idea of You, The Underdoggs, Gen V, The Exorcist: Believer, Heels, The Other Black Girl, Reptile, Rustin, The Beanie Bubble, Moon, Swarm, Fantasy Football, Violent Night, The Promised Land, Hardboiled, Hammer, Blueberries Adrian Lozano √ó Adrian Lozano Herrera Compositor Growing up in Venezuela, Adrian earned his degree in Graphic Design and began his creative journey working with tech companies that specialized in reselling electronic parts and accessories. As part of the marketing department, he was constantly challenged to think outside the box to improve the advertising for the products. He used his knowledge in motion graphics, design, and creative content. Adrian‚Äôs experience led his journey to San Francisco, where he completed his Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Visual Effects at the Academy of Art University in 2017. After graduation, he moved to Los Angeles to begin his career in the industry. Freelancing gave him a variety of experiences between companies and projects. He was able to work on a plethora of TV shows, motion pictures, and advertising projects, which lead to networking with the many talented people in the industry. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm honored to be part of such a passionate, supportive, and collaborative team; grateful for the chance to continue growing alongside my peers.‚Äù The Gorge, Before, Masters of the Air, The Marvels, Haunted Mansion, Disenchanted, Star Trek: Picard, Insecure, Army of the Dead, Perry Mason, Stargirl, Bad Boys for Life, Tom Clancy‚Äôs Jack Ryan, Stay Out Stay Alive, Life and the Lady, The World of Steam, This Is Heaven Stacey Suss √ó Stacey Suss Production Coordinator Stacey has always had a passion for storytelling and art, which naturally blended into a lifelong interest in animation and film. She combined film studies and fine arts classes to receive a BFA in Interdisciplinary Studies from the University of Georgia, and later went on to earn an MFA in Animation from the Savannah College of Art and Design. Stacey first entered the VFX industry in 2021 as a Production Assistant at Industrial Light & Magic, before joining the Whiskytree team in 2024 as a Production Coordinator at their new Alpharetta office. Stacey enjoys working in production where she has an overhead view of the show and can support artists throughout the VFX pipeline. She acts as a liaison between the crew and clients by prepping and sending artist submissions and relaying feedback to the team. Her day-to-day also includes assisting with scheduling, client communication, and organizing and optimizing workflow wherever needed. She feels most at home working in highly collaborative environments and always appreciates the opportunity to challenge herself to learn new skills and build experience. In her spare time she enjoys reading, attending concerts and theatrical productions, and exploring new environments both locally and abroad. ‚ÄúIt is a pleasure to work alongside the talented and resourceful people at Whiskytree. They are a studio dedicated to pushing boundaries and contributing to impactful creative projects.‚Äù Day of Reckoning, Before, Wicked, Indiana Jones and the Dial of Destiny, Dungeons & Dragons: Honor Among Thieves, Babylon, Prey WHISKYTREE¬Æ 818 Fifth Ave, Suite 100 San Rafael, CA 94901 Main 415.456.5400 THE WHISKYTREE SOUTHERN CORPORATION¬Æ 161 Kimball Bridge Road, Suite 300 Alpharetta, GA 30009 Main 770.766.7600 @General @Sales WHISKYTREE¬Æ 818 Fifth Ave, Suite 100 San Rafael, CA 94901 Main 415.456.5400 @General @Sales √ó The Studio Whiskytree is a small yet powerful team of digital artists that is consistently entrusted with bringing the stuff of dreams to life. Since our beginning in 2007, we have been blessed to attract talented individuals with varied background who have contributed to the success and tight-knit culture of our team. We can be found at 818 5th Avenue which is located in the heart of beautiful San Rafael, California, and is also the seat of Marin County. Our office is a short commute from both the East Bay and San Francisco as well as from Sonoma County and Napa Valley. In this way, we are lucky to get the best of both city life and small town living. This is a project role with the possibility of becoming a full-time staff position. Candidates for this role must be based in Georgia. Responsibilities: Create photorealistic assets and props using 3D and 2D tools and techniques Establish continuity between sequences and shots Construct and layout assets to maintain continuity Meet deadlines while maintaining a high level of productivity Interface with production effectively, participating in the success of the company Requirements: Minimum of 1 year of professional experience in feature film visual effects or games Superior 3D modeling, texturing, lighting, and rendering abilities Bachelor‚Äôs degree in industrial design, graphic design, or similar art & design disciplines Strong traditional art and photography skills Excellent written and verbal communication skills Ability to work in a self-directed manner and in a collaborative team environment Highly proficient in the use of Maya and Photoshop Strong working knowledge of Z-Brush/Mudbox/MARI Nuke experience a plus To Apply: Send an email to ro@whiskytree.com that contains the following: Subject line: Assistant Generalist ‚Äì your name A signed Whiskytree Southern Corporation Content Submission Agreement ‚Äì https://whiskytree.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/01/TWSC_CSA_2024.pdf Your resume and cover letter Your date of availability A link to your website or portfolio No phone calls please. √ó Introduction Please send the following by email with the subject line ‚ÄúPosition of Interest submission ‚Äì your name.‚Äù A signed Whiskytree Inc Content Submission Agreement Your resume and a cover letter explaining your interest in the position A link to your portfolio/ reel where we can view your most recent, mind-blowing work Availability date We make every effort to reply via email within 2-6 weeks, but due to the large volume of applications we receive, it is not always possible to respond directly to each applicant. However, you will receive an email acknowledging receipt of your application. Thank you for your interest in Whiskytree and for taking the time to submit your information. The Adventure Begins! Andor √ó Andor Whiskytree was brought on by ILM to work on the Star Wars series Andor, the story of thief turned revolutionary Cassian Andor. Our team contributed to the environments seen on Niamos and Coruscant. For the Niamos beachfront environment we were tasked with set and sky replacements as well as ocean augmentations. Our Generalist team modeled hero building assets and props to integrate into the scene. We then passed the environments to ILM for comp integration. Our contributions to Coruscant can be seen in the transportation hub interior environment. Our set extensions brought this scene to life, and we completed the composites for these shots as well. Wakanda Forever √ó Black Panther: Wakanda Forever Wakandans fight to defend their nation from intervening world powers after the death of King T‚ÄôChalla in Black Panther: Wakanda Forever. Whiskytree created the Wakandan Bush and Riverbank environment for ILM that surrounds Ramonda and Shuri when Namor rises from the water to confront them. Our team used set lidar and location reference from ILM to create this CG environment. We integrated dozens of assets into this set including terrain plots, moonlit sky, atmospherics, and a cyc which ILM composited into final shots. The Captain √ó The Captain A routine flight turns nightmarish in Andrew Lau‚Äôs The Captain. Tasked with recreating the infamous Sichuan Airlines Flight to Lhasa,¬† a core team choreographed and prevized all shots in-house. With roughly 500 shots, a handful of CG artist built 37,000 square kilometers of Western China using open source data. Our FX team generated over 170 unique cloud assets for the general terrain and for the storm. Inside the storm, additional rain and sleet effects marked the various phases of danger in the storm. Working with a data centric light rig, we were able to pull from over 750 procedural HDR skies on a per shot basis. The team built the A319 to-spec using extensive on-set reference, blueprints, and technical manuals while combining practical set constraints. The massive environment also included two to-scale takeoff and landing airports, all coming together and contributing to a wild, edge of your seat ride! Rogue One √ó Rogue One: A Star Wars Story Up and coming Director Gareth Edwards and ILM brought on Whiskytree for work on the film Rogue One: A Star Wars Story. Whiskytree‚Äôs contribution to this amazing project consisted of several CG environments. We created Wobani and the imperial labor camp along with modeling and animating the prisoner transporter. Whiskytree also comped several shots of the final battle scene that took place on Scarif. Obi-Wan Kenobi √ó Obi-Wan Kenobi ILM tasked Whiskytree with bringing the beautiful planet of Alderaan to life for the series Obi-Wan Kenobi. We were responsible for the planet‚Äôs full CG establishing shots. With over 100 shots, our team worked closely with ILM to capture the scenic snow-capped mountains, forestry, and cityscape. Whiskytree was tasked with CG environment work, volume set extensions, asset integration and creation, lighting, and comp. Our team thoroughly enjoyed working on such stunning environments and being a part of the Obi-Wan effort. Foundation √ó Foundation Whiskytree‚Äôs contributions to Apple TV‚Äôs Foundation can be seen in the final episode of Season One. Our studio was responsible for the time lapse shot showing the growing civilization on Terminus. We created and integrated terrain, vegetation, buildings, machinery, digital characters, clouds, and atmosphere into the scene. We then passed off the animated and lit environment for plate integration. League Of Legends √ó League of Legends: Clash The Clash League of Legends online promo was created in collaboration with Riot Games and Director Dave Meyers. The spot was filmed in L.A. with on-set supervision from Whiskytree. Our work consisted of full CG environment creation and set extensions, ranging from the concept and imagining of a dark pit in a gamer lounge, to PC gaming screen overlays and replacements. Not to mention the first promo animation of the Nautilus, a major League of Legends character. Whiskytree completed final comp as well as final conform for the spot. Thor: Ragnarok √ó Thor: Ragnarok For the third installment in the Thor series, Director Taika Waititi and Marvel came to Whiskytree for the continued development of Asgard. This is a world that Whiskytree knows well after having worked on Asgard in all three films in the franchise. Asgard is a grand and golden city and Whiskytree was responsible for many of the full CG establishing shots in the film. Throughout the film, bifrost travel is heavily featured. Generating final comps of all assigned shots, we worked on creating FX enhancements for the observatory and its surroundings, adding nebulas to the sky, generating mist and fog to the waters below, as well as developing the origin point of the bifrost bridge through space. Masters of the Air √ó Masters of the Air Masters of the Air tells the true story of the U.S. 100th Bomb Group, following B-17 bomber crews on dangerous daylight missions over Europe from 1943 to 1945.The nine-part series features historically accurate air combat, with VFX by Whiskytree depicting mission-specific damage, flak, and enemy defenses. In Part Four, the focus shifts to a tense train ride through Nazi-occupied Paris. Whiskytree recreated the route using historical maps, footage, and CG to digitally rebuild 1943 Paris. The D-Day episode features a large-scale recreation of the Normandy invasion, built using aerial photos, AI-enhanced concept art, and detailed CG assets including B-17s, P-51s, landing craft, and moving ground troops. Lighting effects were added with Gaffer to create dramatic sunlight and atmosphere. The team also digitally recreated Nuremberg to portray the brutal POW marches, blending historical architecture with slight artistic tweaks for narrative impact. Whiskytree delivered hundreds of visual effects shots across the series, enhancing historical authenticity and emotional depth. The Gorge √ó The Gorge In the final moments of The Gorge, Whiskytree was tasked with transforming the cliffs of Malibu into a believable hotel setting in the French countryside. Using AI-generated concept art as a starting point, the team developed a clear visual direction before building out the scene with detailed CGI. Key elements included: Hotel Structures: Digitally crafted facades matching period French architecture Geography: Rolling hills and village paths extending the landscape Water & Rocks: CG elements added realism and depth By blending AI-driven design with advanced VFX, the team turned a California location into a stunning, cinematic French Village. Monster Hunt 2 √ó Monster Hunt 2 In a follow up to the Chinese blockbuster hit Monster Hunt, Whiskytree teamed up with Base FX and Director Raman Hui for the long anticipated sequel, Monster Hunt 2. This film features a luscious tree filled environment which had not yet been seen. Working with a partial practical set, Whiskytree was tasked with comp work and set extensions on over 300 shots. We also constructed the CG monster world environment based on a concept by Raman. Whiskytree created the final comp for some shots while others were passed onto Base FX for monster animation. Elysium √ó Elysium Neill Blomkamp directed this science fiction thriller in which Whiskytree created the surface of the luxurious space habitat called Elysium. With trillions of polygons to contend with, this project was not only a success creatively for our client, but also an envelope-pushing technological endeavor that lead to our company presenting to the Academy of Motion Picture Sciences to be considered for an Academy Award. ¬© Whiskytree, Inc    |   All Rights Reserved Website: Design - Stacy Tang |   Concept and imagery - Whiskytree   | Build - Entropic Studio Page load link Find us at our new location in ALPHARETTA, GEORGIA The Whiskytree Southern Corporation is OPEN for BUSINESS!
